canonical_explanation.text: A polygon is a closed figure made of line segments. Triangles have 3 sides and angles totaling 180°. Triangles can be classified by sides (equilateral, isosceles, scalene) or by angles (acute, right, obtuse). Quadrilaterals have 4 sides and angles totaling 360°. Types include square, rectangle, parallelogram, rhombus, and trapezium. Pentagon has 5 sides, hexagon has 6 sides.
rules: Equilateral triangle: all sides equal, all angles 60°
Isosceles triangle: two sides equal, two angles equal
Scalene triangle: all sides different, all angles different
Square: all sides equal, all angles 90°
Rectangle: opposite sides equal, all angles 90°
Parallelogram: opposite sides equal and parallel
Rhombus: all sides equal, opposite angles equal
Trapezium: one pair of parallel sides

questions.question_text: A triangle with all three sides equal is called:
questions.explanation_correct: An equilateral triangle has all three sides of equal length and all three angles of 60°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Equilateral = equal sides. All 3 sides are the same, and all angles are 60°.

questions.question_text: A triangle with two equal sides is called:
questions.explanation_correct: An isosceles triangle has exactly two sides of equal length and two equal angles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Isosceles triangle = 2 equal sides, 2 equal base angles.

questions.question_text: A triangle with no equal sides is called:
questions.explanation_correct: A scalene triangle has all three sides of different lengths and all three angles of different measures.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Scalene = all sides different, all angles different.

questions.question_text: A triangle with one angle equal to 90° is called:
questions.explanation_correct: A right triangle (right-angled triangle) has one angle exactly equal to 90°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If one angle = 90°, the triangle is a right triangle.

questions.question_text: A triangle in which all angles are less than 90° is called:
questions.explanation_correct: An acute triangle has all three angles less than 90°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: When all three angles are less than 90°, it is an acute triangle.

questions.question_text: An equilateral triangle is also isosceles.
questions.explanation_correct: An equilateral triangle has all 3 equal sides. Since it has at least 2 equal sides, it qualifies as isosceles too.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Every equilateral triangle is also isosceles (it has 2+ equal sides), but not every isosceles is equilateral.

questions.question_text: Each angle of an equilateral triangle measures:
questions.explanation_correct: All angles in an equilateral triangle are equal. Since angle sum = 180°, each angle = 180° ÷ 3 = 60°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 180° ÷ 3 = 60°. Each angle of an equilateral triangle is 60°.

questions.question_text: The sum of all angles in a triangle is:
questions.explanation_correct: The angle sum property of a triangle states that all three angles add up to 180°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Angle sum of any triangle = 180°. This is called the angle sum property.

questions.question_text: The sum of all angles in a quadrilateral is:
questions.explanation_correct: The angle sum of any quadrilateral is 360°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: All four angles of a quadrilateral add up to 360°.

questions.question_text: Two angles of a triangle are 50° and 60°. The third angle is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Angle sum = 180°. Third angle = 180° − 50° − 60° = 70°.

questions.question_text: Three angles of a quadrilateral are 90°, 80°, and 100°. The fourth angle is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Angle sum = 360°. Fourth angle = 360° − 270° = 90°.

questions.question_text: A quadrilateral with all sides equal and all angles 90° is a:
questions.explanation_correct: A square has all four sides equal and all four angles equal to 90°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Square = all sides equal + all angles 90°.

questions.question_text: A quadrilateral with opposite sides equal and all angles 90° is a:
questions.explanation_correct: A rectangle has opposite sides equal and all four angles equal to 90°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rectangle = opposite sides equal + all angles 90°.

questions.question_text: A quadrilateral with all sides equal but angles NOT all 90° is a:
questions.explanation_correct: A rhombus has all four sides equal, but its angles are not necessarily 90° (opposite angles are equal).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rhombus = all sides equal, opposite angles equal, but angles need not be 90°.

questions.question_text: A quadrilateral with exactly one pair of parallel sides is a:
questions.explanation_correct: A trapezium has exactly one pair of parallel sides.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Trapezium = one pair of parallel sides. Parallelogram has two pairs.

questions.question_text: In a parallelogram, opposite sides are:
questions.explanation_correct: In a parallelogram, opposite sides are both equal in length and parallel to each other.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Parallelogram has 2 pairs of parallel, equal sides.

questions.question_text: Every square is a rectangle.
questions.explanation_correct: A square has opposite sides equal and all angles 90°, which satisfies the definition of a rectangle. So every square is a special rectangle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A square meets all conditions of a rectangle (opposite sides equal, all angles 90°), plus it has all sides equal.

questions.question_text: Every rectangle is a square.
questions.explanation_correct: A rectangle needs opposite sides equal and all angles 90°, but its sides need not all be equal. Only if all sides are equal does it become a square.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Not every rectangle is a square. A rectangle with length ≠ breadth is not a square.

questions.question_text: How many sides does a pentagon have?
questions.explanation_correct: A pentagon has 5 sides. 'Penta' means five.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pentagon = 5 sides. The prefix 'penta' means five.

questions.question_text: How many sides does a hexagon have?
questions.explanation_correct: A hexagon has 6 sides. 'Hexa' means six.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hexagon = 6 sides. The prefix 'hexa' means six.

questions.question_text: A polygon with 3 sides is called a:
questions.explanation_correct: A 3-sided polygon is a triangle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 3 sides = triangle. 'Tri' means three.

questions.question_text: A triangle has sides 5 cm, 5 cm, and 8 cm. It is:
questions.explanation_correct: Two sides are equal (5 cm each), so it is an isosceles triangle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Two sides are equal (5 = 5), one is different (8). This makes it isosceles.

questions.question_text: A triangle has sides 3 cm, 4 cm, and 5 cm. It is a:
questions.explanation_correct: All three sides are different (3 ≠ 4 ≠ 5), so it is a scalene triangle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: No two sides are equal, so it is scalene. (It is also a right triangle since 3² + 4² = 5².)

questions.question_text: A triangle has angles 90°, 45°, and 45°. By its angles, it is:
questions.explanation_correct: One angle is 90°, so it is a right triangle. By sides, it is also isosceles (two 45° angles means two equal sides).
questions.explanation_incorrect: One angle = 90° makes it a right triangle.

questions.question_text: A triangle has angles 120°, 30°, and 30°. By its angles, it is:
questions.explanation_correct: One angle (120°) is greater than 90°, so it is an obtuse triangle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 120° > 90°, making this an obtuse triangle.

questions.question_text: A triangle has angles 40° and 70°. The third angle is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sum of angles in a triangle = 180°. Third = 180° − 40° − 70° = 70°.

questions.question_text: Three angles of a quadrilateral are 85°, 95°, and 100°. The fourth angle is:
Which quadrilateral has both pairs of opposite sides parallel?
questions.explanation_correct: A parallelogram has both pairs of opposite sides parallel and equal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Parallelogram = 2 pairs of parallel sides. Trapezium = only 1 pair.

questions.question_text: A rhombus is a type of parallelogram.
questions.explanation_correct: A rhombus has both pairs of opposite sides parallel and equal, so it is a special parallelogram where all 4 sides are equal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since a rhombus has 2 pairs of parallel sides, it is indeed a parallelogram.

questions.question_text: How many pairs of parallel sides does a trapezium have?
questions.explanation_correct: A trapezium has exactly one pair of parallel sides.
questions.explanation_incorrect: By definition, a trapezium has 1 pair of parallel sides.

questions.question_text: A regular polygon has:

options.text: All sides and all angles equal

questions.explanation_correct: A regular polygon has all sides of equal length AND all angles of equal measure.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Regular polygon = equal sides + equal angles. Example: equilateral triangle, square.

questions.question_text: Can a triangle have two right angles?

options.text: No, because 90° + 90° = 180° leaving 0° for the third
Yes, if it is very large

questions.explanation_correct: If two angles are 90° each, their sum is 180°, leaving 0° for the third angle. Since an angle cannot be 0°, a triangle cannot have two right angles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 90° + 90° = 180°. The third angle would be 0°, which is impossible. So a triangle cannot have two right angles.

questions.question_text: Can a triangle have two obtuse angles?
questions.explanation_correct: Two obtuse angles would each be > 90°, so their sum > 180°. Since the angle sum of a triangle is 180°, this is impossible.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Two obtuse angles > 90° + 90° = 180°. No room for a third angle. Impossible.

questions.question_text: A rectangle has ___ pairs of parallel sides.
questions.explanation_correct: A rectangle has 2 pairs of parallel sides (top-bottom and left-right).
questions.explanation_incorrect: A rectangle has 2 pairs of parallel sides.

questions.question_text: The diagonals of a rectangle are:
questions.explanation_correct: The diagonals of a rectangle are equal in length and bisect each other.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rectangle diagonals are equal. They bisect each other but are NOT perpendicular (unless it is a square).

questions.question_text: Which of the following is true about a square?

options.text: It is a rectangle and a rhombus
It is a rectangle but not a rhombus
It is a rhombus but not a rectangle
It is neither a rectangle nor a rhombus

questions.explanation_correct: A square has all angles 90° (rectangle) and all sides equal (rhombus). So it is both.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Square = rectangle (all 90° angles) + rhombus (all equal sides).

questions.question_text: In a triangle, if one angle is 90° and another is 50°, the third angle is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Angle sum = 180°. Third angle = 180° − 90° − 50° = 40°.

questions.question_text: A closed figure formed by line segments is called a:
questions.explanation_correct: A polygon is a closed figure made entirely of line segments.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Polygon = closed shape with straight sides (line segments).

questions.question_text: A triangle with sides 6 cm, 6 cm, and 6 cm is:
questions.explanation_correct: All sides equal = equilateral. All angles = 60° (less than 90°) = acute. So it is equilateral and acute.
questions.explanation_incorrect: All sides equal → equilateral. Each angle = 60° → acute.

questions.question_text: In a parallelogram, opposite angles are:
questions.explanation_correct: In a parallelogram, opposite angles are equal (and consecutive angles are supplementary).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Opposite angles of a parallelogram are always equal.

questions.question_text: If two angles of a triangle are 65° and 55°, what type of triangle is it by angles?
questions.explanation_correct: Third angle = 180° − 65° − 55° = 60°. All three angles (65°, 55°, 60°) are less than 90°, so it is acute.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Third angle = 60°. All angles < 90°, so the triangle is acute.

questions.question_text: A polygon with 8 sides is called an ___
questions.explanation_correct: An 8-sided polygon is called an octagon. 'Octa' means eight.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 8 sides = octagon (from 'octa' meaning eight).

questions.question_text: A triangle with one angle greater than 90° is called:
questions.explanation_correct: A triangle with one angle greater than 90° is an obtuse triangle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If any angle > 90°, the triangle is obtuse.

questions.question_text: Which quadrilateral has all sides equal and diagonals that bisect each other at 90°?
questions.explanation_correct: A rhombus has all sides equal, and its diagonals bisect each other at right angles (90°).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rhombus diagonals cut each other at 90° and all 4 sides are equal.

questions.question_text: The sum of angles of a triangle can be 200°.
questions.explanation_correct: The angle sum of any triangle is always exactly 180°, never more or less.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Angle sum of triangle = 180°, always. 200° is impossible.

questions.question_text: Which quadrilateral has equal diagonals and all angles 90°?
questions.explanation_correct: A rectangle has all angles 90° and its diagonals are equal in length.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rectangle has equal diagonals + all right angles. Rhombus has perpendicular diagonals but not all 90° angles.

questions.question_text: How many diagonals does a quadrilateral have?
questions.explanation_correct: A quadrilateral has 2 diagonals — lines joining opposite vertices.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A 4-sided polygon has 2 diagonals.

questions.question_text: Which type of triangle has all angles less than 90° and all sides equal?
questions.explanation_correct: An equilateral triangle has all sides equal and all angles 60° (each < 90°), making it both equilateral and acute.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Equilateral = 3 equal sides, 3 equal angles of 60° (all acute).

questions.question_text: If all four angles of a quadrilateral are equal, each angle is ___°
questions.explanation_correct: Sum = 360°. If all equal: 360° ÷ 4 = 90°. Each angle is 90°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 360° ÷ 4 = 90°. This quadrilateral is a rectangle (or square).

questions.question_text: Rohan drew a quadrilateral with both pairs of opposite sides equal but no angle was 90°. He drew a:
questions.explanation_correct: Both pairs of opposite sides equal and parallel = parallelogram. Since no angles are 90°, it is not a rectangle or square.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Opposite sides equal and parallel but no 90° angles = a general parallelogram.
